poster.title: The Birth of Time: Stealing the Divine Knowledge

text_blocks.body: Prehistoric & Early Sumerian Observations: The Sacred Gaze

text_blocks.heading: "By the light of the stars”
text_blocks.body: Early humans observe repeating patterns in the sky, laying the groundwork for the first calendars.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Left Column)

text_blocks.heading: Moon Phase Diagram
text_blocks.body: Long before clocks or written dates, early hunters and gatherers watched the Moon grow, shrink, and vanish in a steady cycle. By noting how many “big moons” passed, they could tell when seasons changed—time to follow migrating herds, gather ripening berries, or plan the next campsite. The Moon’s shining calendar turned the night sky into a guide for survival.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Left Column)

text_blocks.heading: Counting the Heavens
text_blocks.body: Sumerian priests on a ziggurat track lunar months and solar movements. Their base-60 counting system (using 60 as a key number) gave us 60 seconds in a minute and 60 minutes in an hour
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Left Column)

text_blocks.body: Kidu’s Journey: Forging the Divine System

text_blocks.heading: Seconds
text_blocks.body:
“Sixty drops and my clay pot is full—perfect for one short reading.”
Uses a water clock to measure a quick lesson for apprentices.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Minutes
text_blocks.body:
“One pebble each minute—by the sixtieth pebble the courtyard is swept.”
Oversees chores; easy fractions (½ = 30 min, ¼ = 15 min) split the work.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Hours
text_blocks.body:
“Third hour of daylight—market scales open!”
Announces when traders may begin selling grain.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Day
text_blocks.body:
“Sunset closes the ledger; tomorrow’s page starts at first light.”
Files daily records and plans the next day’s schedule.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Month
text_blocks.body:
“A slim silver crescent means a new month—farmers, sharpen your plows.”
Marks the first visible crescent Moon to start the lunar month and signal planting.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Year
text_blocks.body:
“Twelve big Moons have passed; time to tally storehouses and plan the river cleanup.”
Uses the lunar count to schedule annual projects and civic festivals.
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Days to Months
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.heading: Months to Years
text_blocks.source: Asia cultural innovations Final Answer.xlsx (Center Column)

text_blocks.body: Evolution to Modern Calendars: A Sacred Comparative Timeline

text_blocks.heading: A Global Legacy
text_blocks.body: From the Sumerian base‑60 system to modern time divisions and calendar structures, the ancient quest to measure time continues to shape our world.

layout.layout_concept: Three-column layout: left observational panels + moon phase diagram, center Kidu timekeeping stack, right comparative calendar infographic.

designer_guidance.design_objectives_and_summary: This Asia poster packages the cultural innovation of timekeeping: early sky observation, the Sumerian base‑60 counting legacy, and a designer-built comparative calendar graphic showing how lunisolar systems drift against solar months.

Left Column (Sacred Gaze): Cosmic/temple atmosphere; clearly communicate observation → measurement.
Keep captions short and readable at distance; use strong contrast on dark backgrounds.
Center Column (Kidu): Stacked narrative panels for each unit (seconds → year).
Reserve space for voice-bubble captions and short explainer line per panel.
Right Column (Comparative Calendar Graph: Use a vertical seasons ribbon to anchor both calendars.
Show Gregorian solar months on one side and a lunisolar month system on the other; include clear leap-month indication.

comparative_calendar_spec: See 'Right Column' sheet: seasons ribbon, Gregorian blocks, Hebrew blocks, leap indicators, and call-outs.
